{
  "triples": [
    {"s":"X-ray micro-modulated luminescence tomography (XMLT)", "p":"uses", "o":"X-ray optical components", "modalities":["text"], "confidence":1.0, "evidence":"In XMLT, we treat the X-ray beam as a wave, not just as a stream of particles. That means we can actually use certain X-ray optical components — things that already exist on the market, like X-ray polycapillary lenses."},
    {"s":"X-ray micro-modulated luminescence tomography (XMLT)", "p":"uses", "o":"nanophosphors", "modalities":["text"], "confidence":1.0, "evidence":"When we introduce nanophosphors into the sample — the same luminescent particles we talked about earlier — these particles light up only along the path of the focused X-ray beam."},
    {"s":"X-ray micro-modulated luminescence tomography (XMLT)", "p":"produces", "o":"optical signals", "modalities":["text"], "confidence":1.0, "evidence":"So the spatial resolution of this imaging method is determined entirely by the X-ray focal spot

evidence: When we introduce nanophosphors into the sample - the same luminescent particles we talked about earlier - these particles light up only along the path of the focused X-ray beam.
